comment.body:
Good post, though I have some comments:

>Make sure all writing is devoid of unconsciously learned discrimination.

Speaking of corruption of language, discrimination used to simply mean (before 1900) to make a distinction between two things. One cannot go without discriminating between things and choosing what's best for them.

Here's the older definition:

>Discernment, the act of discriminating, discerning, distinguishing, noting or perceiving differences between things, with intent to understand rightly and make correct decisions.

---

>The internet promotes half-truths do not contribute to them by rushing through a tweet or post.

The Internet can provide for truth, disinformation and half-truths, because the Internet is such a low-level playing field you have to filter everything yourself and determine what's important. Though the Internet is not the only place for half-truths and disinformation, it's pervasive and omnipresent these days whether it be in book publishing, mainstream media, national media, or big tech.
